properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A bitterly cold Arctic air mass is keeping a firm grip on far Northern Ontario. Wind chill values have moderated a little today but extreme cold wind chills near minus 45 are expected to return again tonight into Saturday morning. ### Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-14T08:15:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T16:16:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1727447272.2019
Area: Fort Severn, Peawanuck
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Risk of freezing rain Friday night into Saturday morning. An approaching east coast storm will bring the risk of freezing rain to the area Friday night into Saturday morning. Any freezing rain will transition over the rain during the day Saturday. However, as the system moves away from the area Saturday night, rain will transition back to snow. A quick few centimetres of accumulation is expected in combination with strong gusty winds and colder temperatures. People are advised to monitor future Environment Canada forecasts for additional information. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-14T08:16:30-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall at times heavy will impact much of Nova Scotia. Total rainfall: 40 to 70 mm. Locations: Mainly southwest Nova Scotia and along the Atlantic Coastline. Time span: Saturday morning until Sunday morning. Remarks: Rain, at times heavy, will spread across Nova Scotia on Saturday. The rain will persist Saturday night and then taper to showers Sunday morning over the west. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-14T11:46:53-00:00

properties.Title: Alberta Emergency Alert - Evacuation Of Hamlet Of Brule In Yellowhead County, Alberta Due To Gas Line Break
properties.Summary:
Description: All residents of Brule in Yellowhead County are being evacuated by the municipality. There is an event that has disrupted natural gas supply. Residents who are being evacuated or Brule residents already out of the evacuation area should call the Evacuation Information line at 1-833-334-4630 or go to the Doctor Duncan Murray Centre in Hinton for evacuation registration inquiries.
Expires: 2019-12-20T10:32:09-07:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Yellowhead County, 2019-12-13T10:30:11-07:00, NAADS-CA-AB-AEA1-6150
Area: Yellowhead County
properties.Author: Yellowhead County

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall through the weekend 20 to 40 centimetres of snow are expected from Saturday to Sunday. A low pressure system from the Southern United States will intensify before reaching the province of Quebec on Saturday. An area of heavy snow will develop north of the track. Quickly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Consider modifying any non essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-14T08:18:35-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall and strong winds are expected. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm. Higher amounts possible over the Long Range Mountains. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h, except locally 110 in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: Saturday evening until Sunday morning. Remarks: After a brief period of snow or freezing rain Saturday evening, rain at times heavy will follow for the remainder of the night until tapering to showers Sunday morning. Strong southeasterly winds and very mild temperatures will accompany the rain, leading to significant snow melt and run off. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall possible Saturday into Saturday night. Snow with the the risk of freezing rain will begin overnight Friday night into early Saturday morning. Any freezing rain is not expected to last long and will transition over to snow during the day Saturday. The snow will then continue into Saturday night with total snowfall amounts near 10 cm possible by Sunday morning. The significant snow in combination with strong, gusty winds and falling temperatures will result in difficult travel conditions Saturday night. This snowfall and possible freezing rain is associated with a strengthening east coast storm that will track through New York into Quebec on Saturday. Please monitor future Environment Canada forecasts for additional information. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall expected Saturday. The rain will begin early Saturday morning with total rainfall amounts of 20 to 30 mm likely by late Saturday evening. The rain may become mixed with snow later Saturday evening before it tapers off overnight. This rainfall is associated with a strengthening east coast storm that will track through New York into Quebec on Saturday. Note that Environment and Climate Change Canada uses a rainfall warning criteria of 25 mm or more in 24 hours or less when the ground is frozen and has a reduced ability to absorb rainfall. For the latest information concerning the potential for flooding in your area, please refer to your local Conservation Authority or the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A winter storm with mixed precipitation on the way for this weekend. Locations: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River, and along the coast from Postville - Makkovik to L'Anse-au-Clair. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm possible. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm south of Groswater Bay. Lesser amounts elsewhere. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 km/h. Time span: Saturday night into Sunday. Remarks: Snow, heavy at times, will develop Saturday evening along the Straits and spread to central and the remainder of coastal Labrador through the night. The snow will change through ice pellets and freezing rain to rain on Saturday. Central and inland areas of coastal Labrador could see several hours of freezing rain during the changeover. The rainfall, combined with temperatures well above zero on Sunday could result in significant snowmelt in some areas, especially coastal areas south of Groswater Bay. Anyone planning weather sensitive activities is advised to plan ahead. Travel is expected to become difficult as a result of these conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-14T11:43:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T19:44:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3281403505.2019
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall and strong winds are expected. Total rainfall: 60 to 100 mm. Highest amounts inland. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h, except 120 in the Wreckhouse area. Locations: southwestern Newfoundland. Time span: Saturday evening until Sunday evening. Remarks: Rain will be heavy at times, and will occur in conjunction with very mild temperatures. Any existing snow cover will melt quickly and contribute to an elevated risk of flooding, especially near rivers or creeks and in low lying areas. Strong southeasterly winds will also develop with the arrival of the rain on Saturday evening and shift to strong southwesterly on Sunday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Although there will be moderation of extreme windchill values during the day, extreme windchill values in the -45 to -50 range will come back tonight and persist through the weekend and into next week. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Sant√© at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 km/h. Locations: Nain to Hopedale. Time span: early Sunday morning until Monday afternoon. Remarks: A major winter storm is expected to impact northern Labrador late this weekend into early next week. A combination of heavy snowfall and strong winds will result in poor visibility in blowing snow. The snow may change to rain showers or drizzle for a few hours late Sunday night or Monday morning before changing back to snow or flurries later in the day. Anyone planning weather sensitive activities is advised to plan ahead. Travel is expected to become difficult as a result of these conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain and strong winds for this weekend. Total Rainfall: 30 to 60 mm. Higher amounts along the Atlantic coast. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h with higher gusts near the Cape Breton Highlands. Locations: Nova Scotia. Time frame: Saturday morning into Sunday. Remarks: Rain will spread across the province Saturday and become heavy, at times. Strong southerly winds and mild temperatures will lead to significant snow melt and run off. The rain is expected to taper to showers on Sunday. Although coastal flooding is not expected, large waves with rough and pounding surf can be expected along the atlantic coast. A rainfall warning has been issued for counties along the atlantic coast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values remain near -50 this morning for communities near Great Slave Lake. Values are expected to moderate during the day; however they are forecast to approach -50 again tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-14T10:21:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T18:22:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1017572643.2019
Area: Yellowknife Region, North Slave Region including Wekweeti - Whati - Behchoko, Ft. Resolution Region including Hwy. 6
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Freezing precipitation is also possible over some areas. Locations: western Labrador. Total snowfall: 20 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h or higher. Time span: Saturday night until Monday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Saturday night and will likely become heavy at times. The snow is likely to change to ice pellets or freezing rain on Sunday but will transition back to snow Sunday night. Churchill Falls and Churchill Valley may even see a brief period of rain Sunday evening before changing back to snow. Strong northwesterly winds are also expected to develop Sunday night, resulting in poor visibility in blowing snow. Anyone planning weather sensitive activities is advised to plan ahead. Travel is expected to become difficult as a result of these conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-14T11:45:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T19:46:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3882557925.2019
Area: Churchill Valley, Churchill Falls and vicinity, Labrador City and Wabush
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. A cold arctic airmass is expected to remain in place throughout the remainder of this week and into mid next week. Wind chill values will moderate for most regions during the day, then once again fall into the minus 45 to 50 range overnight for the next several days. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-14T09:05:22-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 30 to 60 mm. Locations: southwestern New Brunswick Time span: Saturday morning until Sunday morning. Remarks: Rain, at times heavy, will spread across New Brunswick on Saturday. The rain will persist Saturday night and then taper to showers Sunday morning. The highest rainfall amounts are expected near the Fundy coast. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-14T11:42:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T19:43:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0568099342.2019

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly 80 km/h, except locally 100 km/h in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: late Saturday evening until early Sunday morning. Remarks: Local enhancement in southeasterly flow typically occurs in the vicinities of Cape St. George, Port au Port Bay, and the outer Bay of Islands. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-14T11:35:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T19:36:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0884852420.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Snowfall giving total amounts of 15 to 25 centimetres are expected from Saturday morning through Sunday morning. Additionally, strong winds will cause locally blowing snow beginning Saturday evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. Total rainfall: 50 to 70 mm, except up to 100 mm inland. Locations: southwestern Newfoundland. Time span: Saturday evening until Sunday evening. Remarks: Rain will be heavy at times, and will occur in conjunction with very mild temperatures. Any existing snow cover will melt quickly and contribute to an elevated risk of flooding, especially near rivers or creeks and in low lying areas. Strong southeasterly winds will also develop with the arrival of the rain on Saturday evening and shift to strong southwesterly on Sunday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-14T11:32:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T19:33:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1963993519.2019
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain and strong winds for this weekend. Total Rainfall: 20 to 30 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 90 km/h. Locations: Prince Edward Island and Iles-de-la-Madeleine. Time frame: Saturday morning through Saturday night. Remarks: Rain will spread across the region during the day Saturday and become heavy, at times. Strong southerly winds and mild temperatures will lead to significant snow melt and run off. The rain is expected to taper to showers early Sunday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 120 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: Saturday night. Remarks: Southeasterly winds gusting to 80 km/h will develop Saturday afternoon and increase with gusts reaching 120 km/h by early evening. Winds will ease upon shifting to southerly overnight Saturday night. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain, freezing rain, snow and wind for this weekend. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm over northernmost regions. Total rainfall: 20 to 30 mm over northern and eastern regions. 30 to 60 mm over southwestern regions. Maximum wind gusts: easterly becoming southerly with gusts between 50 and 80 km/h. Locations: New Brunswick. Time span: Saturday morning until Sunday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin overnight tonight over northern regions, and then transition through freezing rain to rain on Saturday. Over central regions, some freezing rain is likely in the morning before temperatures slowly climb above the freezing mark. Over southern regions, rain will prevail for most of the day as strong southerly winds quickly push temperatures well above the freezing mark, leading to significant snow melt and run off. A rainfall warning has been issued for southwestern portions of the province. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-14T11:46:08-00:00
